Paddy Power Betfair PLC (PPB:LSE): Last: 8,320, down 465 (-5.29%), High: 8,735, Low: 8,235, Volume: 72.51k
PM11:14am

hmm

BE11:15am

Who can summarise? Morgan Stanley will do.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Paddy Power Betfair had pre-announced its FY16 revenues of £1,551m (+18%, +11% cc), and EBITDA of £400m (+35%, MSe £398m) is in the middle of its previously guided range of £390-405m. The merger integration is on-track with management maintaining its expectation for an incremental £30m in synergy benefits in 2017, in addition to leveraging the scale, technology and brand positioning of the combined group. Current trading is in-line with company expectations overall with 12% constant currency growth in sportsbook stakes (+16% in FY16), though gaming has not fully recovered from a weak Q4. A full year dividend of 165p per share is in-line with the group's target of a 50% payout ratio. The company finished the year with a small net cash position; the company makes no comment on leverage except that the board keeps the capital structure under regular review. We don't expect to make any changes to our forecasts.

BE11:16am

For FY17 we forecast net revenue of £1.78bn (+15%), EBITDA
of £486m (+22%) and EBIT of £413m (+24%), and we don't expect to change these forecasts. Trading on a 2017e P/E of 20.4x and EV/EBITDA of 13.6x, the valuation has dropped since the merger, and is now within historical ranges. Given the company's strong cash conversion and growth, these multiples drop quickly to 16.4x and 10.7x in 2019e respectively. We estimate that the group could return £25 per share over the next 4 years if it were to adopt the old Paddy Power leverage target of 1x net debt/EBITDA with each additional turn of leverage funding c.£6 per share in cash returns. We lay out our investment case in more detail in this note. With its strong execution in high-growth end markets, we see continued upside risks to forecasts in the coming years, and rate the shares Overweight with a £106 price target.

BE11:16am

And Davy .............

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Given that Paddy Power Betfair issued a post-close statement in
mid-January, there are no major surprises in the 2016 numbers
reported this morning. That should not take away from the fact
that the group grew EBITDA by 35% in 2016 (to £400m) with
18% growth in group revenues and a 380 basis point
improvement in EBITDA margins (to 25.8%). Further
improvements in efficiency are expected in 2017 and beyond.
So what is new in today’s statement? On the plus side,
Australia really stands out. Australian EBITDA came in £13m
above our forecast with the earnings beat coming via better
cost control. That bodes well as the majority of actions taken by
management in relation to improved Australian efficiency are
only likely to be fully felt in 2017. In addition, staking growth in
Australia year-to-date is 11 percentage points ahead of our
forecast (at +19% versus +8% forecast). Upgrades to our
Australian forecasts look likely.

BE11:16am

On the flip side, the weakness in online gaming, first
experienced in Q4, persists. Lower levels of gaming cross-sell
and reduced VIP activity led to gaming revenues being down
1% in Q4. With no improvement year-to-date, we are minded
to assume no gaming growth in 2017, particularly given the
lack of a major summer football tournament which often leads
to spill-over cross-sell. That said, much of this slowdown was
already built into our forecasts.

BE11:16am

Ultimately, we continue to see good scope for earnings
upgrades over the next two years, driven by overly
conservative Australian forecasts and on-going positive
operational gearing in online. While online growth will
inevitably slow, we feel that this is already baked into our
numbers. Use of the balance sheet to further strengthen the
group strategically remains a valuable option.

BE11:19am

Shawbrook requested ..........

11:19 am
Shawbrook Group PLC (SHAW:LSE): Last: 319.00, down 0.3 (-0.09%), High: 320.00, Low: 304.20, Volume: 757.22k
PM11:19am

Intriguing this

BE11:19am

Came off a bit at the open on the rejecting of 330p ....

11:20 am
BE11:20am

... came back on the assumption that Pollen Street will probably bump by 20p or so and this is all a bit choreographed.

BE11:21am

Results are fine enough. Guidance same. Barclays can summarise those to save us time.

BE11:21am

Shawbrook’s FY16 results came in slightly ahead of our expectations. PBT of £91.4m is 6% ahead driven by top line and up 14% yoy – NII of £197m 3% head of Barclays. Slightly higher tax means net profits of £64.8m and diluted EPS of 35.5p is 3.5% ahead, down -4% and -5% yoy respectively. Loan book £4.1bn is in line, up 22% yoy. The cost/income ratio of 45% was lower than expectation of 46%. The cost of risk was lower than projected, at 64bps (we were going for 62bps), or 35bps excluding the control breach impairment. Gross margin of 7.8% was bang in line (Barc f/c 7.8%) and NIM was 5.6% (Barc f/c 5.5%), down from 6.2% in FY15 as expected. Capital position remains strong with the CET1 ratio of 13.3% and the leverage ratio 7.8% at Dec-16. Management also detailed they have drawn down on £120m on TFS so far. The outlook remains confident, with management saying it is cautious of macroeconomic risks but sees no reason to have to scale back growth initiatives at the moment at ROTE of 22-25%.

We believe the potential offer from two PE houses (we observe that PE houses are more or less universal sellers of businesses to the market at this time) highlights the value Shawbrook offers.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Shawbrook has announced that it is not willing to recommend the 330p offer per share for the company, made by a consortium of Pollen Street Capital (which owns 38.9% of the company) and BC Partners, which was announced to the market on Friday (3 March). The Board rejected the initial proposal of 307p, which led to the subsequent revised offer of 330p. Despite Shawbrook's assertions that it remains confident in its strategy as a public company, we do not rule out a further third improved bid by the consortium and BC Partners. We continue to expect the starting level for a successful bid to be at least 350p, which is 10x our 2017E EPS forecast. 2016 results came in line with our forecasts. Underlying PBT was £91.4m vs. Liberum £92.0m. The net interest margin was in line with our forecast and the CET1 Ratio was 13.3% vs. Liberum of 12.9%

BE11:28am

Shore target 400p ...........

BE11:28am

As noted in our trading comment yesterday, we think this materially undervalues the group with our current fair value (ahead of any changes following the results) set at 400p. We therefore think that the Board has come to the correct decision in rejecting this approach, but it now needs to convince the market it can deliver the growth strategy that was set out at the Capital Markets day in May 2016. With the shares currently trading at a discount to both the offer price and out fair value estimate, we reiterate our positive stance. BUY

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Price today seems fair enough, given the risk-reward.

PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Campling of Northern trust

PM11:32am

Despite today’s positive price reaction to FY results Just Eat’s stock price remains well below the price (583p) it was before revealing disappointing order volumes, the KPI, in January. FY16 results are ahead of street consensus with revenue of £375.7M above consensus (Source: FactSet) £371.8M and underlying EBITDA of £115.3M versus consensus £111M. Just Eat expect FY17 revenues of between £480.0-495.0M and EBITDA of between £157.0-163.0M, which are both only broadly inline with street expectations (£490M and £158M respectively). For a stock trading on 31x F12M P/E and 7.5x P/Sales we would have expected upside to guidance relative to consensus. Last year in March the company guided 2016 revenues 640bps above consensus and EBITDA 880bps above consensus.

While Just Eat is profitable in eight out of 12 territories, the UK remains critical. The UK represents 63% of segment revenues, 65% or segment orders and 94% of underlying segment EBITDA (FY16 data). The ability to drive 8% in ARPO (Average Revenue Per Order) in the UK seems mainly due to a 100bps increase in the standard commission rate passed through in April 2016 rather than organic increase in wallet spend.

PM11:33am

Just Eat had already announced FY16 group order volume growth of +42% (+36% on LFL basis) in January. This also showed that the KPI ‘UK order growth’ slowed in 4Q16 to just 24%. Now that compares to UK order growth in the same quarter of 2015 of c.44%. The same we see as a significant deceleration of growth at a time competition has intensified and is the first quarter in which Uber and Amazon have entered the market. We expect challenges to Just Eat’s planned path to maintaining high growth and their need to defend mind and market share as UK competition intensifies will likely pressure EBITDA margins. Order growth in the UK is expected to be mid-to-high teens for Just Eat in 2017. Two years ago, in 1H17 it was growing at 50%. Add in the fact that key executives who have led the business are now leaving or recently departed and with risk of slowing growth and potential margin risk we find the valuation of F12M 31x P/E and 7.5x P/Sales too rich to stomach. We remain sellers of Just Eat.

11:33 am
PM11:33am

Actually had forgotten about the executive departures

PM11:33am

Makes today's pop all the more bemusing

BE11:34am

It's down to only 31x? That's nearly sane. Ish.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

For a more postive view: Numis, again.

BE11:34am

The shares have fallen 14% ytd, a combination of its slowing orders in the UK (+22% in Q4 vs. +34% in Q1-3) and David Buttress (CEO) announcing he is to step down, in our view. A slowing of percentage growth from 31% for the #1 UK market player seems entirely reasonable (NSe +10% UK order growth FY17). We also believe a short-term CEO void should be manageable. We remain positive on the growth opportunities for the online food delivery market (from call to clicks), JE's ability to drive commission rates and the operating leverage from its technology platform. We would therefore use the share price correction, with the shares trading at 22.4x 2018E PER (32% CAGR) as an attractive buying opportunity.

BE11:35am

...... and Canaccord. Always keen.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

The shares are down 11% year-to-date, having reacted to the news, in February, that CEO David Buttress is stepping down. In our view the stock looks cheap on a 2018 multiple, trading on just 13.8x EV/EBITDA which is below the UK Internet peer group (on 14.5x) despite offering significantly higher earnings growth, and 23.5x PER. We remain positive.

BE11:36am

That's the general theme. Consider it a companion piece to the "Paddy Power's expensive" argument above, if only to emphasise how bloody difficult it is to trade into results.

BE11:42am

Now, SDI Four's only directors (apart from the secretary) are Dotun Adegoke and Rachel Stockton, Sports Direct's senior buyer and head of Customs and VAT respectively.

11:42 am

BE11:43am

11:43 am

PM11:43am

11:45 am

BE11:46am

BE11:47am

There's a lot of nose-holding required to invest in Sports Direct, for any number of reasons, and it's this kind of statement that emphasises it.

Worldpay Group PLC (WPG:LSE): Last: 268.70, down 6.3 (-2.29%), High: 276.20, Low: 263.00, Volume: 5.68m

PM11:49am

UBS have one of these Q&A things you like

PM11:49am

Q: Will regulatory changes disrupt the sector positively or negatively?
Both – regulatory changes (particularly PSD2) are likely to be disruptive for the payments sector, as they open up the potential for new entrants to compete. But we see a number of mitigating factors – and even opportunities for those willing to invest. We do not see the reforms as a general negative for the sector.
Q: Which areas in payments will show the fastest revenue growth rates?
The outlook for the hardware businesses (Gemalto / Ingenico) remains highly uncertain in 2017E, given the slowdown seen in the US. We expect transactions services businesses will continue to show mid-single-digit growth rates overall, and those exposed to online transactions look likely to show the fastest growth rates (mid-teens).
Q: Will EBITDA margins expand across the sector?
Yes – we expect EBITDA margins to expand for processing businesses, as we see competitive pressures remaining in check and industry growth sustained.

11:49 am
PM11:49am

Mid-single-digit growth priced in. We estimate that only low-single-digit revenue growth is priced in across the sector, assuming no margin expansion. The lack of a consensus view makes it challenging to assess what the market is pricing in for the sector (although we would note that the EU names generally trade at a discount to US peers) but from our interactions with investors it is clearly something increasingly in focus.

PM11:49am

Our top pick remains Worldpay, given its exposure to online transaction growth and as cash generation improves substantially this year, along with the potential for margin leverage. We also rate Worldline at Buy, as we see upside optionality to estimates as the implications of PSD2 play out, and rate Paysafe at Buy as we believe regulatory fears are overdone.

PM11:49am

It's a long note -- i will try and usual place it later

11:49 am
PM11:49am

BE11:52am

Otherwise, Mitie mentioned on the right.

11:52 am
Mitie Group PLC (MTO:LSE): Last: 201.00, down 9.1 (-4.33%), High: 203.90, Low: 191.50, Volume: 2.65m
PM11:52am

Ouch

BE11:53am

Jefferies saying "keep away!"

11:52 am
BE11:53am

The shares have been volatile as the market assesses the outlook for recovered earnings and the balance sheet. In our view, the new CEO is taking many necessary steps to rehabilitate MITIE but risk/reward is unfavourable ahead of the KPMG accounting review. We downgrade from Hold to Underperform.

BE11:54am

It's an outsourcer so it's accounting haze, inevitably.

BE11:54am

MITIE in FY20E. We consider a scenario in which Healthcare exit is followed by disposal of Property Management (c8% dilutive and lowers ND/EBITDA by c0.5x) and assess the outlook for recovered earnings and the balance sheet under more conservative accounting policies.

A 4-5% recovered EBITA margin. Peers to MITIE’s facilities management division have historically sustained a 4-6% EBITA margin but wage inflation is a headwind for the entire sector and our analysis suggests a 4-5% range may be more realistic in the future. Key swing factors include national living wage pass-through and recovery of stranded overhead.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Accounting is a key issue for the shares as prepayments/accrued income have expanded considerably and material accounting restatement is a major pillar of the bear case. We conclude that: 1) POC accounting may have flattered group EBITA by c£20-30m annually for the past three years with the cash impact offset by a receivables discounting facility; 2) £203m other accrued income is a material unknown; 3) capitalised mobilisation costs have distorted less in recent years.

BE11:54am

In our view, the March and September 2017 covenant tests will be the point of maximum risk as £14m above-the-line one-offs aren’t excluded from FY17E EBITDA for covenant calculation purposes. A £20-25m reduction in FY17E EBITDA from the KPMG review could cause the 3x covenant to be breached.
125-255p bear/bull fair value range. Our bull case assumes no material prospective accounting changes, swift non-core asset disposals and a 5.2% recovered EBITA margin. Our bear case assumes covenant breach after the KPMG review, a 10% equity placing and a 4.1% recovered EBITA margin.
We downgrade FY17E and FY18E EPS by 23% and 20% respectively (to sit 5-7% below consensus), and assume that the final dividend is passed but the 4.0p full year payout is maintained in FY18E.

BE11:55am

We reduce our PT from 195p to 175p. This is based on a 60/40 weighting of our 125-255p bear/bull fair value range. Risks include: pass-through of cost inflation and rising leverage.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

That's Kean Marden, who I'd not argue with.

PM11:58am

PM11:58am

Slowest sales performance in stationery & household appliances
Within the survey we note weak relative positions from stationery, household appliances, which may be reflected in recent sales from AO World^ (AO., Hold at 146p), footwear and clothing. The strongest relative trading performance came from furniture, which may be reflected in the recent revenues of the likes of Carpetright^ (CPR, Buy at 228p) and their respective cohort, and house textiles. We are curious why furniture may be selling but appliances not?
Sluggish February for non-food lines
In February 2017 total retail sales rose by 0.4% against a comparative of 1.1%, the three month (3M) moving average is 0.8% and 0.9% on a 12M outlook. On a LFL basis UK sales fell by 0.4% against a 0.1% comparative. Whilst non- food sales in the December-February fell by the 2.6% referenced above, food sales rose by 2.0% on a total basis with LFL sales also higher; +0.6%. 12M total food sales growth was 1.2%.

PM11:58am

Sound grocery performance, values boosted by easing deflation
The sound nature of the grocery market is said to have benefited, according to the respected Institute of Grocery Distribution (IGD), from amorous Britain with a 'particularly strong Valentine's Day this year'. The robust grocery performance is supportive of our OVERWEIGHT stance on the UK superstores in our view, a stock cluster where we shall gain further insight with the publication of preliminary results from Wm. Morrison Supermarkets+ (MRW, House Stock at 245p) on the 9th March and J. Sainsbury^ (SBRY, Buy at 261p) on the 16th March through its Q4 update.

11:58 am
PM11:58am

There's that grocers-like-inflation theme again

PM11:58am

Tougher but not tough
Looking ahead, CY2017 has started in muted fashion for the non-food retail world. That said the days are only starting to brighten whilst Easter and the associated events, for example Mother's Day, are a little later this year, which may yet stimulate trade. In terms of fundamentals as we see them, the levels of employment in the UK are high and consumer confidence is sound if perhaps a little more fragile in the New Year. There is concern though about where the UK economy goes post the Referendum and the wages-prices conundrum.
We continue to see CY2017 as a tougher year for the UK retail segments, particularly non-discretionary albeit not a tough one; the data still throws up mixed messages like furniture being the strongest segment of trade in February. Whilst we are positive on the grocers, the General Retailers require more stock selectivity in our view; we tend to like pure play online, self-help and good discount.
